sa8:0.2: 11-14. Past Is Impermanent, Painful, Empty, and Not Self
sa8:1.2: One time, the Buddha was staying at Anāthapiṇḍada’s Park in Jeta’s Grove of Śrāvastī.
sa8:2.1: It was then that the Bhagavān addressed the monks,
sa8:2.2: “Past and future form is [11] impermanent … [12] painful … [13] empty … [14] not self, so why wouldn’t present form?
sa8:2.4: They don’t look back to past form, don’t wish for future form, and become free of desire for present form.
sa8:2.5: They’re correctly headed toward complete cessation.
sa8:3.1: Thus, past and future feeling … perception … volition … consciousness is [11] impermanent … [12] painful … [13] empty … [14] not self, so why wouldn’t present consciousness?
sa8:3.3: They don’t look back to past consciousness, don’t wishing for future consciousness, and become free of desire for present consciousness.
sa8:3.4: They’re correctly headed toward complete cessation.”
sa8:4.1: When the monks heard what the Buddha taught, they rejoiced and approved.
